Graphical abstract The perovskite LaCoO3 (LCO) was used as catalyst for preferential oxidation of CO (PROX). LCO was synthesized via the modified Pechini method and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and CO– and H2– temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Different reductive and oxidative pretreatments were applied to systematically vary the Co oxidation state in order to examine its effect on catalytic performance and to single out active site requirements. Upon reduction at increasing temperature, LaCoO3 transformed to brownmillerite-type La2Co2O5, exsolved Co0 nanoparticles supported on La2O3 and, upon reoxidation, to Co3O4/La2O3. The Co oxidation state of the various catalysts correlated with their CO2 selectivity: LCO containing only Co3+ exhibited 100 % CO2 selectivity in a wide temperature window, whereas La2Co2O5, Co/La2O3 and Co3O4/La2O3 had markedly lower selectivity. It is suggested that Co3+ is crucial and that the strong resistivity of LaCoO3 towards reduction is responsible for the high and stable CO2 selectivity over a temperature range of 100 °C–220 °C. Higher oxygen concentration further broadens the PROX window. Keywords Perovskite Preferential Oxidation of CO Brownmillerite Exsolution Co Oxidation State Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Transition metal oxides are efficient catalysts for the preferential oxidation of CO in excess of H2 (PROX; Eq. (1) ) [1,2]. The interest in these low-cost materials is driven by their high catalytic activity and stability, which is comparable to that of noble metal-based catalysts, while being less sensitive to CO poisoning. (1) PROX: CO + H2 + 0.5O2 → CO2 + H2 ΔH298 = − 283 kJ/mol Selective CO oxidation in H2 has relevance for H2 purification technologies required for the operation of fuel cells [3]. To prevent loss of H2, the reaction must be CO2 selective, which is challenging due to competitive adsorption of CO and H2 on the catalyst surface and similar enthalpies of CO oxidation (Eq. (2) ) and H2 oxidation (Eq. (3) ): (2) CO + 0.5 O2 → CO2 ΔH298 = − 283 kJ/mol (3) H2 + 0.5O2 → H2O ΔH298 = − 242 kJ/mol The goal is thus to achieve a high CO oxidation rate at moderate temperature and high selectivity, avoiding not only H2 oxidation but also CO methanation, paralleled by stability against deactivation. While supported Pt catalysts are highly effective [4,5], their high cost and limited availability have shifted attention toward non-noble metal alternatives, such as transition metal oxides. Ceria supported copper oxides show excellent PROX performance [6–10], i.e., they exhibit high activity at low temperatures but operate within a relatively narrow temperature window (50–130 °C) while showing limited stability at higher temperatures. Cobalt oxides, based on their low temperature CO oxidation activity [11–17], have been particularly promising for PROX as well [1,2,18–20]. In our previous studies, Co3O4 was active but decently selective for PROX between 75 °C and 150 °C, while pronounced H2 oxidation set in at higher temperature [21]. Above 250 °C, cobalt oxide reduction (Co3+ to Co2+ and Co0) occurs, leading to methanation. Adding 10 % CeO2 to Co3O4 increased the PROX activity and made Co3O4 more difficult to reduce, resulting in a wider operation temperature window [20,21]. Mixed oxide-supported Co3O4 was reported to be less prone to reduction and high activity/selectivity was maintained up to 250 °C [22]. For cobalt oxide, both CO oxidation and PROX have also been extensively studied by in situ/operando techniques [14,19,21]. In an alternative approach, perovskite-type oxides (ABO3) have also been shown to be active in CO and hydrocarbon oxidation, NOx reduction, dry reforming of methane, CO, CO2 and hydrocarbon hydrogenation [23–29]. For hydrocarbon and CO oxidation, among the La-based perovskites (A=La), the order of activity was (B=) Co > Mn > Ni > Fe > Cr [24,28,29]. For example, Vaz et al. reported that substituting the B site of LaNiO3 by Co3+ enhanced the CO oxidation activity [30]. Moreover, partial A substitution by rare earth elements improved the structural stability, making these materials resistant towards reduction at low temperature and thermal sintering, which is important for high-temperature applications [31–33]. With respect to PROX on LaCoO3, Magalhaes et al. reported that adding cerium on La(1-x)CexCoO3 (x = 0, 0.05 and 0.1) led to higher PROX onset temperature [33]. Fiuza et al. found that substituting Co by Fe in LaCo0.9Fe0.1O3 induced slightly lower CO conversion during heating, while after 30 min at 330 °C CO conversion and CO2 selectivity were similar to those of LaCoO3 [34]. Adding Pt to LaCoO3 even negatively affected performance due to H2 spillover and over-reduction of the perovskite surface, with metallic Co leading to CH4 formation. Partial substitution of Co by Ru was reported in [35]. When Co was substituted by V (LaCo1-xVxO3, x = 0, 0.05 and 0.1), 50 % CO conversion was achieved at 25 °C lower temperature, but with a narrower temperature window in CO2 selectivity [36]. Altogether, even without modifications, the pure LaCoO3 is quite an active oxidation catalyst. However, in perovskite catalysis, especially at high temperatures, the in situ generation of new phases by (partial) decomposition and/or metal exsolution has been repeatedly reported [37–41]. During the reaction a mixture of phases may be obtained, which makes interpretation of reactivity more difficult, though. The current study thus focused on the active LaCoO3 catalyst and specifically aimed at examining different (preferentially pure) phases/compositions that were systematically prepared by reductive and oxidative pretreatments, to determine the impact of the Co oxidation state on PROX performance. Note that, in variance to common practice, the pretreatments were not intended to increase performance, but to obtain specific target compositions. As described below, apart from the initial LaCoO3, La2Co2O5, exsolved Co on La2O3 and (reoxidized) Co3O4/La2O3 were obtained, with marked differences in activity/selectivity. Among all catalysts, LaCoO3 exhibited 100 % CO2 selectivity over a wide temperature range (100–220 °C), which was attributed to its Co3+ oxidation state. Accordingly, reductive pretreatment above 300 °C lowers both activity and CO2 selectivity. Reoxidation led to “Kirkendall-type“ [42,43] but unselective Co3O4 nanoparticles on La2O3. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst Preparation The LaCoO3 (LCO) catalyst was synthesized via the sol–gel based Pechini method [44,45], using La(NO3)2·6H2O (from Sigma, for R&D) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (from Fluka, purum p.a.), as illustrated in Fig. S1. Citric acid monohydrate (CA, from Riedel-de Haen) was used as chelating agent and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA, from Fluka, puriss. p.a.) as reaction medium. EDTA (0.02 mol) was dissolved in ammonium hydroxide aqueous solution (50 mL; 28.0–30.0 %), adding 0.03 mol CA while stirring at room temperature (RT). Each metal salt (0.01 mol) was dissolved in 25 mL deionized water (molar ratio of total metal ions:EDTA:CA = 1:1:1.5) and added simultaneously and dropwise to the EDTA/CA solution in a three-necked flask at RT. The pH was adjusted to 9 with ammonium hydroxide solution, and the solution stirred at 90 °C overnight until a viscous gel formed. The gel was dried at 120 °C for 24 h (yielding the catalyst precursor) and finally calcined in static air at 600 °C (10 °C min−1) for 4 h to obtain the LaCoO3 perovskite catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization by TGA, XRD, BET, HRTEM, and TPR To determine the best-suited calcination temperature of the catalyst precursor, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch TGA 209C, heating the sample (dried at 120 °C in static air for 24 h) in synthetic air (50 mL min−1) from RT to 700 °C at 10 °C min−1. For phase analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on a Philips XPERT-PRO diffractometer with Cu K-α radiation (1.5406 Å), operating in Bragg-Brentano reflection geometry at 40 kV and 40 mA with 2θ scanning from 10° to 90° (step size of 0.02° and a dwell time of 0.37 s per step). Phase analyses and Rietveld refinements were performed with the HighScorePlus software (JCPDS data base). To determine the BET surface area (SBET), N2 adsorption at −196 °C was performed in an ASAP 2020 Micromeritics apparatus. The sample was preheated under vacuum (<0.013 mbar) at 250 °C for 2 h. Evaluation of SBET was based on the linear part of the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, pore size distributions were obtained applying the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) equation to the isotherm desorption branch, and total pore volume was estimated from the N2 uptake at a P/P 0 of 0.99. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), yielding information on particle size, morphology and lattice structure, was performed on a TECNAI F20 microscope operated at 200 kV. The sample powders were deposited on copper grids coated with lacey carbon film (without using liquids). Energy dispersive X-ray fluorescence (EDX) was applied for elemental mapping of selected regions. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and CO-TPR were applied to characterize the catalyst reducibility at atmospheric pressure. Approximately 20 mg catalyst was loaded in a continuous-flow fixed-bed quartz reactor between two quartz wool plugs. Before each TPR, potential surface species (adsorbed hydrocarbons, carbonates, water/hydroxyls) were removed by oxidation in synthetic air (50 mL min−1) at 400 °C for 30 min (heating rate 10 °C min−1). Samples were cooled to 30 °C under a flow of synthetic air and purged with He for 30 min. The cleaned samples were then exposed at room temperature to either a mixture of 5 vol% H2 in He (H2-TPR) or 5 vol% CO in He (CO-TPR), at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1, subsequently heated to 800 °C (10 °C min−1). In addition, 50 vol% H2 in He or 1 vol% CO in He were used, mimicking PROX reaction conditions. H2 consumption and CO2 evolution were analysed by an online quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS; Prisma Plus QMG 220, Pfeiffer Vacuum) equipped with a secondary electron multiplier (SEM) detector. 2.3 Catalytic preferential oxidation of CO (PROX) Preferential CO oxidation on calcined LaCoO3 (LCO) and differently pretreated catalysts was carried out in a continuous-flow fixed-bed quartz reactor under atmospheric pressure. 20 mg of sample were mixed with 100 mg quartz sand to avoid mass and heat transfer limitations and were loaded into the reactor in between two quartz wool plugs. Before each PROX experiment, a fresh catalyst sample was pretreated in oxidizing and reducing atmosphere, as described below. After cooling to RT, the PROX reaction was performed in 1 vol% CO, 1 vol% O2, 50 vol% H2 and 48 vol% He (total flow 50 mL min−1), heating to 400 °C at a rate of 2 °C min−1. A CO flow of 0.5 ml min−1 corresponds to 0.0204 mmol min−1 or 2.05·1017 CO molecules per second. The concentration of reactants (CO, O2, H2) and products (CO2, H2O, CH4) in the outlet stream were monitored by an online QMS (Prisma Plus QMG 220, Pfeiffer Vacuum) equipped with an SEM detector and by gas chromatography (Agilent 6890) using a HP-PLOT Q column and a flame-ionization detector (FID) with a methanizer and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CO conversion (Eq. (4) ), CO2 yield (Eq. (5) ), CO2 and H2O selectivity (Eq. (6) and (7*) , respectively) and turnover frequency (TOF) (Eq. (8**) ) were calculated from the calibrated GC data: (4) X CO ( % ) = n ̇ CO IN - n ̇ CO OUT n ̇ CO IN ∙ 100 (5) CO 2 y i e l d ( % ) = n ̇ CO 2 n ̇ ∑ carbon ∙ 100 (6) S C O 2 % = n ̇ CO IN - n ̇ CO OUT 2 ( n ̇ O 2 IN - n ̇ O 2 OUT ) ∙ 100 (7) S H 2 O % = 100 - S C O 2 ( T < 300 ° C ) (8) TOF = n ̇ CO ∙ X CO 60 ∙ 100 ∙ n Cobalt n ̇ : M o l / m i n b a s e d o n a r e a o f CO , O 2 o r C O 2 p e a k f r o m c a l i b r a t e d g a s c h r o m a t o g r a p h y . n ̇ ∑ c a r b o n : T o t a l a r e a o f t h e p e a k s o f c a r b o n - c o n t a i n i n g c o m p o u n d s ( CO , CO 2 and CH 4 ) . X CO : C o n v e r s i o n o f C O . n Cobalt : M o l o f c o b a l t i n 20 m g c a t a l y s t . *CH4 was only formed above 300 °C and only for specific catalysts (see below). **The temperature-dependent turnover frequency, TOF, the number of CO molecules converted per Co atom and per second, calculated with respect to nCobalt in 20 mg catalyst, can therefore not be calculated for La2O3. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties (XRD, BET, TEM) The optimum calcination temperature of the synthesized catalyst precursor was determined by TGA (Fig. S2a). The most pronounced weight loss of organic/inorganic material occurred between 100 °C and 420 °C, with a smaller loss at 420 °C-600 °C. Above 600 °C, no further decomposition was observed. The phase composition of the catalyst precursor and after air calcination at 450 °C or 600 °C (4 h each) were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. S2b). Only after calcination at 600 °C, strong reflections at 32° (110) and 33° (104) were observed, characterizing the stoichiometric crystalline LaCoO3 (LCO) perovskite with rhombohedral unit cell of space group R 3 ¯ c (ICDD PDF no: 04–015-9695; rhombohedral). The average crystallite size of LCO calcined at 600 °C was 25 nm, as calculated by Rietveld refinement. BET indicated a specific surface area (SSA) of 18 m2 g−1, an average pore diameter of 29.7 nm and a pore volume of 0.10 cm3 g−1. The BET results for all samples are summarised in Table S1. 3.2 Reduction behavior (H2-TPR and CO-TPR) When measuring H2-TPR (Fig. 1 a) of LaCoO3 (calcined at 600 °C) in 5 vol% H2, two consecutive reduction steps were observed [33,46–49]. The first peak at 420 °C is attributed to reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ (motivating the low temperature reduction (LTR) pretreatment at 450 °C below), whereas the second peak at 600 °C is attributed to Co2+ reduction to metallic Co0 (motivating the high temperature reduction (HTR) pretreatment at 650 °C below). This assignment was confirmed by XRD and TEM (cf. Figs. 2 and 3 ). Up to 450 °C, a (near) surface reduction takes place, likely removing surface oxygen. Upon increasing the temperature to 650 °C, bulk reduction occurs. Oxygen loss upon reduction may destabilize the perovskite structure and, as Co0 atoms are too large to remain in the lattice, they exsolved from the bulk, forming Co0 atoms/clusters on La2O3 [50]. During CO-TPR (Fig. 1 b) in 5 vol% CO, CO2 peaks appeared at 325 °C, 400 °C, and 650 °C. The two peaks at 325 °C and 400 °C are attributed to the stepwise reduction of Co3+ to Co2+, i.e., LaCoO3 → La3Co3O8 → La2Co2O5 [49,51,52]. Between 500 °C and 750 °C the perovskite was fully reduced, forming exsolved Co0 and La2O3 (cf. Figs. 2 and 3). The shoulder at 550 °C is likely due to CO disproportionation (Boudouard) reaction [53]. Additionally, TPR was performed with 50 vol% H2 and 1 vol% CO (Fig. 1 c and d, respectively), mimicking PROX conditions. The different concentrations of reducing gases shifted the reduction temperatures as expected: in both cases higher concentrations led to lower reduction temperatures. The different concentrations of H2 and CO (1 vs 5 vs 50 %) were chosen, on the one hand, to compare reduction by H2 and CO at the same concentrations (5 %) and, on the other hand, to use conditions similar to those under PROX (1 % CO and 50 % H2). The different concentrations somewhat shifted the reduction temperatures, but they were still much higher than the selective PROX window described below. Catalyst reduction under PROX reaction conditions is thus only to be expected above 300 °C. 3.3 XRD and TEM of catalyst pretreatment Based on the results of H2-TPR, the 600 °C calcined LaCoO3 powder (before each experiment the catalyst was oxidized again at 400 °C to remove contaminants adsorbed from air) was subjected to gas treatments to modify catalyst structure and composition (Co oxidation state). H2-treatment at 450 °C (low temperature reduction, LTR) reduces Co3+ to Co2+, whereas high temperature reduction (HTR) at 650 °C further reduces Co2+ to metallic Co0. Thus, the pretreatments described below create a defined (initial) state for catalyst characterization and kinetic tests, while the re-oxidation treatment was motivated by our previous studies on Co3O4 [14,21,54]. The terminology used below is: 1. Ox 400: the (stored, calcined) LCO catalyst was oxidized in synthetic air (50 mL min−1) at 400 °C for 30 min (heating rate 10 °C min−1) and then cooled to RT in synthetic air, assuring a defined starting state. 2. Ox 400/LTR: after (1), the sample was reduced in 5 % H2 in He at 450 °C for 1 h and cooled to RT in the same gas. 3. Ox 400/HTR: after (1), the sample was reduced in 5 % H2 in He at 650 °C and cooled to RT in the same gas. 4. Ox 400/HTR/Ox 150: after (3), the sample was reoxidized in synthetic air (50 mL min−1) at 150 °C for 30 min (heating rate 10 °C min−1) and then cooled to RT in the same gas. The resulting crystalline phase were examined by XRD, N2 adsorption and TEM. XRD after Ox 400/LTR revealed a brownmillerite-type structure (i.e., La2Co2O5; 04-008-6405; orthorhombic) and La2O3 (04-002-2528; hexagonal) (Fig. 2 b) [55], whereas after Ox 400/HTR metallic Co0 and La2O3 were observed (Co; 04-015-0419; cubic and La2O3; 04-002-2528; hexagonal) (Fig. 2 c), in line with H2-TPR. Despite room temperature sample transfer in air, no significant Co oxidation was detected. The Ox 400/HTR/Ox 150 sample showed Co3O4 (01-78-5634; cubic), CoO (04-03-2617; cubic) and La2O3 (04-002-2528; hexagonal) phases (Fig. 2 d). Table 1 summarizes the phases, crystallite sizes (from Rietfeld refinement) and SBET of all materials. Fig. 3 a–l shows TEM, HRTEM images and EDX mapping acquired after the different pretreatments of LCO. After Ox 400, lattice fringes (Fig. 3 b) of 0.272 nm spacing indicated (110) planes of the LCO perovskite, matching well the ICDD database (PDF no: 04-015-9695). Particle size ranged from 30 nm to 70 nm, often with hexagonal/polygonal shapes. STEM-EDX maps (Fig. 3 c) of La (orange), Co (purple) and O (blue) confirmed their homogeneous distribution. After Ox 400/LTR (Fig. 3 d–f), HRTEM revealed somewhat larger and irregular La2Co2O5 particles (50 nm to 100 nm) with characteristic lattice fringes of 0.793 nm (020), according to the ICDD database (PDF no: 04-008-6405, orthorhombic). EDX mapping (Fig. 3 f) indicated that the homogeneous elemental distribution was maintained. After Ox 400/HTR, Fig. 3 g–i shows irregularly shaped Co and La2O3 particles in the size range of ∼20 to 100 nm (the difficulty of differentiating Co and La2O3 did not allow to obtain size histograms). Lattice fringes of 0.216 nm spacing indicated (111) planes of Co (PDF no: Co; 04-015-0419; cubic), whereas those at 0.329 nm the (222) planes of La2O3 (PDF no: 04-002-2528; hexagonal). To differentiate Co and La2O3, we concentrated on specific particles in “profile view” and used EDX analysis to confirm that – at least in these cases − exsolution occurred and that cobalt was positioned on/near the surface. Elemental La, Co and O EDX maps are displayed in Fig. 3 i. Despite room temperature sample transfer to the microscope in air, no significant oxidation of the Co nanoparticles was detected, in line with XRD. After reoxidation at 150 °C, irregular particles (∼25–100 nm) were still observed (Fig. 3 j). An EDX line scan (Fig. S3) showed that Co3O4 nanoparticles remained on the surface of La2O3. The image contrast in Fig. 3k even points to a hollow Co3O4 nanoparticle (analogous ones shown in Fig. S4), pointing to a Kirkendall effect [42,43]. In addition to examining the cobalt oxidation state via XRD and HRTEM phase analysis, carrying out H2-TPR of already reduced catalysts can further verify it. As illustrated in Fig. S5a, the catalyst was initially reduced at 450 °C for 30 min, followed by cooling to room temperature. Subsequently, the catalyst was exposed to a second reduction at 650 °C without any intermediate treatment. Notably, as depicted in Fig. S5b, the characteristic peak corresponding to the reduction from Co3+ to Co2+ at 420 °C (LaCoO3 to La2Co2O5) had disappeared and only the peak at 600 °C characteristic of the reduction from Co2+ to Co0 was observed. Following the reduction at 650 °C for 30 min, the catalyst was once again cooled to room temperature. It was then reoxidized at 150 °C in a 20 vol% oxygen atmosphere, followed by cooling to room temperature. As shown in Fig. S5c, the oxidized cobalt species were subsequently re-reduced with a broader peak between 300 and 500 °C [56,57]. Importantly, above 550 °C, the reduction peak associated with the transition from Co2+ to Co⁰ (La2Co2O5 to Co/La2O3) was not present anymore, indicating the completion of the reduction process in the preceding reduction. 3.4 PROX performance The four different pretreatments created the four targeted different catalyst compositions, which allowed to assess the reactivity of Co in different oxidation states: LaCoO3 (Co3+), La2Co2O5 (Co2+), metallic Co0 on La2O3, and Co3O4 (Co3+ and Co2+) on La2O3. Thus, temperature programmed PROX (1 vol% CO, 1 vol% O2, 50 vol% H2, 48 vol% He) was examined for all states by MS. The catalytic results are presented in Fig. 4 , with temperature windows of selective CO2 formation marked with a grey background. For LaCoO3 (Fig. 4 a), solely CO2 was produced in a temperature window of 100 °C-220 °C. From 220 °C to 320 °C both CO2 and H2O were formed, whereas mostly H2 oxidation occurred at higher temperature. Accordingly, the CO consumption and CO2 formation decreased. Reverse water gas shift (RWGS: CO2 + H2 ⇄ CO + H2O) [58] and methanation (CO + 3H2 → CH4 + H2O; CO2 + 4H2 → CH4 + 2H2O) did not occur below ∼ 300 °C, as shown in Fig. S6 [59]. Gas phase oxygen was typically fully consumed above 300 °C, which also holds true for the other catalysts. On La2Co2O5, only a small amount of H2O was detected below 190 °C (Fig. 4 b). From 190 °C to 310 °C, unselective CO2 and H2O formation occurred. The lacking PROX activity seems to be related to the Co2+ oxidation state in the La2Co2O5 perovskite. Above 310 °C, H2O formation dominated, but no methane was observed. On Co/La2O3 (Fig. 4 c), both CO2 and H2O were produced from 125 °C to 290 °C, with the lack of selectivity likely due to Co oxidation. At higher temperatures, H2O formation initially dominated, but methanation occurred above 325 °C due to the presence of metallic cobalt, as observed in [21]. Overall, Co/La2O3 showed a behaviour in between La2Co2O5 and Co3O4/La2O3 (see below), pointing to initial oxidation and re-reduction of Co. On Co3O4/La2O3 (Fig. 4 d), preferential CO oxidation occurred from 75 °C to 150 °C (lower temperature than on the other catalysts but much narrower range than LCO), whereas both CO2 and H2O formation were produced from 150 °C to 270 °C. At higher temperature, H2O formation dominated first, while above 300 °C methanation set in. Although the performance of Co3O4/La2O3 is similar to (pure) Co3O4 [21], the supported Co3O4 shows even better selectivity below 150 °C. As PROX is strongly exothermic, the higher activity of Co3O4/La2O3 than Co/La2O3 (c.f. Fig. 4c, 4d, and 4f) may also affect the methanation onset temperature in favor of Co3O4/La2O3. Pure La2O3, measured for comparison, hardly showed any PROX activity (Fig. 4 e). Methane formation did not occur on LaCoO3 and La2Co2O5, but only on Co/La2O3 and Co3O4/La2O3 at higher temperature. As known from literature, metallic cobalt facilitates methanation [21,33,60] (note that above 300 °C, Co3O4 is reduced to Co0 [21]). The ∼75 °C lower CH4 onset temperature of Co3O4/La2O3 may be due to Co redispersion upon the preceding re-oxidation step. In contrast, LaCoO3 and La2Co2O5, not containing Co0, did not produce any CH4 under the same conditions. Although the MS sensitivity to reactants (CO:1.05; O2:0.86; H2:0.44) and products (CO2:1.4; H2O:0.9; CH4:1.6) is known, for quantitative measurements gas chromatography was applied. Fig. 4 f shows the temperature-dependent CO conversion and TOF of the different pretreated catalysts, as determined by GC. On Co3O4/La2O3 (Ox 400/HTR/Ox 150) the CO conversion to CO2 started at ∼75 °C and reached 90 % at 225 °C. For LCO, the onset temperature was 100 °C and conversion reached 95 % at 300 °C. The onset temperature of CO conversion was 130 °C for Co/La2O3 and 190 °C for La2Co2O5, with both reaching 80 % conversion at 300 °C. Please note that Co3O4/La2O3 was the best in terms of CO conversion at low temperature, but not in CO2 selectivity. Using 2 vol% oxygen on LaCoO3 (Fig. S7), the selective PROX region was even extended to 240 °C with the CO oxidation rate remaining high up to 370 °C. Higher oxygen concentration thus widens the PROX window, shifting the onset of water formation to higher temperature, likely by delaying/hindering perovskite surface reduction. The CO2 yield as a function of temperature, determined by gas chromatography, is displayed in Fig. 5 a for all catalysts, showing a trend of Co3+ > Co0 > Co2+. Above ∼250 °C-300 °C, the CO2 yield decreased due to the competing water and methane formation, but depending on the catalyst. The CO2 and H2O selectivity are plotted in Fig. 5 b, demonstrating the wide 100 % selectivity window of LaCoO3. Table 2 summarizes the observed (selective/unselective) temperature windows, including benchmark systems from literature [21,61,62]. Temperature programmed PROX ( Fig. 5 b) demonstrated that LaCoO3 was selective even in a wider temperature window (100 °C-220 °C) than Co3O4/La2O3 (75 °C-150 °C). La2Co2O5 and Co/La2O3 did not exhibit selective temperature ranges. Methanation, which consumes hydrogen and reduces the selectivity of CO oxidation, was observed on Co/La2O3 and on Co3O4/La2O3 due to metallic cobalt being present at high temperature [21]. For CO oxidation on Co3O4, Co3+ was often regarded an active centre [12,13,54,63–65]. Similarly, Co3+ of the LaCoO3 perovskite may favour CO2 selectivity [21,60]. Co3+ apparently provides stronger adsorption sites for CO [13] than for H2, facilitating preferential CO oxidation, whereas metallic Co⁰ favors H2 dissociation/activation, thereby impacting selectivity towards methane [66]. Clearly, the reaction onset temperature of PROX on LCO (100 °C) is higher than that of Co3O4 (75 °C), but the temperature window is twice as wide on LCO. Based on the measured BET surface area of LCO and La2Co2O5 “TOF-like values” were calculated, assuming a (110) LaCoO3 surface and a (200) La2Co2O5 surface (see the SI). Clearly, this is an approximation for pure phase catalysts (and could not be calculated for Co/La2O3 and Co3O4/La2O3) but should still be handled with care. Reaction rates at 200 °C normalized per surface area can be found in Table S1. Further experiments varying the gas mixture at 200 °C were performed to confirm the robustness of the PROX selectivity (Fig. 6 ). First, the LCO catalyst was heated to 200 °C in the PROX mixture, leading to CO oxidation (I). Then, when CO was switched off, exclusively hydrogen oxidation took place after some induction period (II). The rate of H2 oxidation increased with time suggesting a slow modification of the catalyst under these conditions (e.g., by removal of adsorbed carbonates or surface reduction). Thereafter, CO was added again, with the selectivity switching back to CO oxidation (III). After turning off oxygen, in the CO/H2 mixture no methanation was observed (IV). When oxygen was added once again, CO oxidation occurred straight away (V), reaching the same amount of CO2 as in (I) and (III). In pure H2 atmosphere, no water formation was detected (VI), whereas after oxygen addition water formation occurred instantaneously (VII). As compared to (II), in the preceding period (VI), carbonate removal or surface reduction had already occurred, so that there was no delay in water formation. When CO was added, the selectivity changed back to CO oxidation (VIII). During all experiments at 200 °C, no methanation occurred. Altogether, this cycling experiment clearly demonstrates that the LCO PROX activity and selectivity were largely reversible at 200 °C (I, III, V, VIII) and that changes in the gas composition did not irreversibly modify the surface and bulk structure of the catalyst, highlighting the excellent performance of the LaCoO3 catalyst. To examine the LCO catalyst stability, time-on-stream (TOS) measurements were performed at 150 °C (in the centre of the selective temperature window) (Fig. S8). LCO showed stable 10 % CO conversion at 150 °C over a period of 10 h. Then, the temperature was increased to 160 °C (for 1 h), followed by further increase to 170 °C (for 1 h), revealing good stability without deactivation. 4 Conclusions The current study was based on a LaCoO3 (LCO) perovskite catalyst for preferential CO oxidation (PROX) up to 400 °C, but specifically aimed at determining the impact of the Co oxidation state. Accordingly, different (preferentially pure) target phases/compositions were systematically prepared by reductive and oxidative treatments of LCO and examined for PROX (thus, at first hand, the pretreatments were not intended to simply increase performance). Subjecting LCO to low temperature H2 reduction (LTR) at 450 °C produced a Brownmillerite-type structure La2Co2O5 (accompanied by a small amount of La2O3), whereas high temperature H2 reduction (HTR) at 650 °C led to exsolved metallic Co0 supported on La2O3. Reoxidation of this catalyst at 150 °C yielded Kirkendall-type Co3O4 nanoparticles on La2O3, but without major implications on the catalytic properties. EDX mapping and lattice fringe analyses corroborated the presence of Co in the intended oxidation states and, for the (nearly) pure phases, a rather homogeneous distribution of La, Co, and O. The four different pretreatments thus created four different catalyst compositions, allowing to assess the reactivity of Co in different oxidation states: LaCoO3 with Co3+, La2Co2O5 with Co2+, Co0 on La2O3, and Co3O4 (Co3+ and Co2+) on La2O3. The catalytic PROX tests revealed that LaCoO3 with Co3+ exhibited the best performance in terms of activity, selectivity, and selective operation range. The LTR sample (Co2+, La2Co2O5), and the HTR sample (Co0, Co/La2O3) were both unselective, showing additional water formation. Reoxidation of the HTR sample led to Co3O4/La2O3, again being selective, with a CO oxidation onset temperature similar to Co3O4, but lower than for LCO. Nevertheless, the selective temperature window of LCO was twice as wide as that of Co3O4 with H2O formation setting in at higher temperature. Methanation occurred at high temperature for Co/La2O3 and Co3O4/La2O3, due to the presence of metallic cobalt (with Co3O4 partly reduced under reaction conditions). In contrast, LCO perovskite and La2Co2O5 seemed resistant towards reduction during reaction, so that no CH4 was formed. Cycling experiments demonstrated that the PROX activity/selectivity of LCO were reversible at 200 °C, so that changes in the gas composition did not irreversibly modify the surface and bulk structure of the catalyst. The LCO catalysts also exhibited sufficient stability at 150 °C for longer times. Although the reductive pretreatments lowered the performance, they still enabled improved insight in the active species required, i.e., that the Co3+ oxidation state should be maintained. Thus, higher oxygen concentration broadens the PROX window and shifts the water formation onset to higher temperatures. Altogether, this study emphasized that catalyst performance was strongly influenced by the cobalt oxidation state. The results indicated that LCO is a highly selective and stable catalyst for preferential CO oxidation in hydrogen rich atmosphere, while the other catalysts exhibited varying degrees of selectivity and reactivity. Operando spectroscopic studies are currently performed to learn more about molecular details of the PROX reaction on LCO. coredata.dc:description: The perovskite LaCoO3 (LCO) was used as catalyst for preferential oxidation of CO (PROX). LCO was synthesized via the modified Pechini method and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), and CO– and H2– temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Different reductive and oxidative pretreatments were applied to systematically vary the Co oxidation state in order to examine its effect on catalytic performance and to single out active site requirements. Upon reduction at increasing temperature, LaCoO3 transformed to brownmillerite-type La2Co2O5, exsolved Co0 nanoparticles supported on La2O3 and, upon reoxidation, to Co3O4/La2O3. The Co oxidation state of the various catalysts correlated with their CO2 selectivity: LCO containing only Co3+ exhibited 100 % CO2 selectivity in a wide temperature window, whereas La2Co2O5, Co/La2O3 and Co3O4/La2O3 had markedly lower selectivity. It is suggested that Co3+ is crucial and that the strong resistivity of LaCoO3 towards reduction is responsible for the high and stable CO2 selectivity over a temperature range of 100 °C–220 °C. Higher oxygen concentration further broadens the PROX window.

coredata.dc:title: Preferential CO oxidation (PROX) on LaCoO3–based catalysts: Effect of cobalt oxidation state on selectivity
